qas.question: Which agreement was signed in 1954 by writers, linguists, and literary critics?
On what principle did the Novi Sad Agreement focus upon?
Who was given the task of creating a dictionary in the Novi Sad Agreement?
What did Serbian writers and linguists sign in 1967?

plausible_answers.text: "Serbs, Croats and Montenegrins share a single language with two equal variants that have developed around Zagreb (western) and Belgrade (eastern)"

qas.question: What was the conclusion of the agreement backed by Matica srpska and Matikca hrvatska in 2012?

plausible_answers.text: equal status of Cyrillic and Latin scripts, and of Ekavian and Ijekavian pronunciations

qas.question: What did use of the latin alphabet insist upon?
In official contexts what should be the name of the Dictionary?
During 1967 how many books were published at the same time?

context: In 1954, major Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists and literary critics, backed by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska signed <b3_0>the <a0_0>Novi Sad Agreement<b3_0/><a0_0/>, which in its first conclusion stated: <b4_0>"Serbs, Croats and Montenegrins share a single language with two equal variants that have developed around Zagreb (western) and Belgrade (eastern)"<b4_0/>. The agreement insisted on the <a1_0><b5_0>equal status<a1_0/> of Cyrillic and Latin scripts, and of Ekavian and Ijekavian pronunciations<b5_0/>. It also specified that <b6_0>Serbo-Croatian<b6_0/> should be the name of the language in official contexts, while in unofficial use the traditional Serbian and Croatian were to be retained. <a2_0>Matica hrvatska and Matica srpska<a2_0/> were to work together on a dictionary, and a committee of Serbian and Croatian linguists was asked to prepare a pravopis. During the sixties <b7_0>both books<b7_0/> were published simultaneously in Ijekavian Latin in Zagreb and Ekavian Cyrillic in Novi Sad. Yet Croatian linguists claim that it was an act of unitarianism. The evidence supporting this claim is patchy: Croatian linguist Stjepan Babić complained that the television transmission from Belgrade always used the Latin alphabet— which was true, but was not proof of unequal rights, but of frequency of use and prestige. Babić further complained that the Novi Sad Dictionary (1967) listed side by side words from both the Croatian and Serbian variants wherever they differed, which one can view as proof of careful respect for both variants, and not of unitarism. Moreover, Croatian linguists criticized those parts of the Dictionary for being unitaristic that were written by Croatian linguists. And finally, Croatian linguists ignored the fact that the material for the Pravopisni rječnik came from the Croatian Philological Society. Regardless of these facts, Croatian intellectuals brought the Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Literary Language in 1967. On occasion of the publication’s 45th anniversary, the Croatian weekly journal Forum published the Declaration again in 2012, accompanied by a critical analysis.
